content:
the consequence for the cause. The worthy Italian saw in
his diet the causeof his long life; while the prerequisite of long life, an extraordi-
narily slow metabolism, a small consumption, was the cause of his meager diet.
He was not free to eat much orlittle as he chose, his frugality was notan act of
“free will“: he became ill when he ate more. But if one is not a bony fellow of this
sort one does not merely do well, one positively needs to eat properly.A scholar
of our day,with his rapid con
